unnormalised: The thing about office calendars, right? It’s like trying to herd cats at Diwali. Everyone’s running around, got their own agenda, and nobody quite agrees on when the fireworks should actually start. You try to schedule a meeting for, say, 2:30 PM on a Tuesday, and suddenly half the team is "unavailable" because it clashes with their "urgent" chai break.
normalised: The thing about office calendars, right? It's like trying to herd cats at Diwali. Everyone's running around, got their own agenda, and nobody quite agrees on when the fireworks should actually start. You try to schedule a meeting for, say, two thirty P-M on a Tuesday, and suddenly half the team is "unavailable" because it clashes with their "urgent" chai break.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on the dreaded "Out of Office" replies. Priya’s off for a week in Kerala, starting 10/11/2024, Rakesh has some "personal work" from 14:00 to 16:00 every Friday. Then there's Aisha, who's perpetually "working from home" but somehow always manages to miss the 11:00 AM stand-up. It's a miracle anything gets done.
normalised: And don't even get me started on the dreaded "Out of Office" replies. Priya's off for a week in Kerala, starting tenth november two thousand and twenty four, Rakesh has some "personal work" from fourteen hundred to sixteen hundred every Friday. Then there's Aisha, who's perpetually "working from home" but somehow always manages to miss the eleven hundred A-M stand-up. It's a miracle anything gets done.

unnormalised: Then there's the time zones! We've got colleagues in Mumbai, Delhi, and even Bangalore, so trying to find a time that works for everyone is like solving a Rubik's cube blindfolded. You suggest 3 PM IST and someone inevitably says, "But that's 5:30 AM my time!" Bhai, I didn’t ask you to work graveyard shifts, did I?
normalised: Then there's the time zones! We've got colleagues in Mumbai, Delhi, and even Bangalore, so trying to find a time that works for everyone is like solving a Rubik's cube blindfolded. You suggest three P-M I-S-T and someone inevitably says, "But that's five thirty A-M my time!" Bhai, I didn't ask you to work graveyard shifts, did I?

unnormalised: And the abbreviations! "EOD," "COB," "ASAP." I swear, HR should hand out a decoder ring with every new employee onboarding package. Try explaining to a new intern that "Please action this by EOD" doesn't actually mean the world is ending. It just means, you know, get it done before 17:00 hrs.
normalised: And the abbreviations! "E-O-D," "C-O-B," "A-S-A-P." I swear, H-R should hand out a decoder ring with every new employee onboarding package. Try explaining to a new intern that "Please action this by E-O-D" doesn't actually mean the world is ending. It just means, you know, get it done before seventeen hundred hours.

unnormalised: Let’s not forget the calendar invites themselves. Subject lines like "Urgent – Project X Update," which then turns out to be a 45-minute discussion about fonts. And the endless reply-all chains: "Thanks!" "Got it!" "Acknowledged!" I’m pretty sure half my workday is just deleting emails that contribute nothing to the sum total of human knowledge.
normalised: Let's not forget the calendar invites themselves. Subject lines like "Urgent – Project X Update," which then turns out to be a forty five minute discussion about fonts. And the endless reply-all chains: "Thanks!" "Got it!" "Acknowledged!" I'm pretty sure half my workday is just deleting emails that contribute nothing to the sum total of human knowledge.

unnormalised: But hey, at least it's a job, right? And who knows, maybe someday we'll all master the art of time management. Until then, I’ll just keep marking myself as "busy" on my calendar and sneaking out for a sneaky samosa at 4:00 PM. Don't tell my boss, OK?
normalised: But hey, at least it's a job, right? And who knows, maybe someday we'll all master the art of time management. Until then, I'll just keep marking myself as "busy" on my calendar and sneaking out for a sneaky samosa at four P-M. Don't tell my boss, O-K?
